channel.title: 华尔街日报热门
channel.description: 用中文浏览华尔街日报热门报道

item.title: California Gov. Gavin Newsom wants to allow private citizens to sue gun manufacturers, modeling his proposal after the legal framework used in the Texas law banning abortions past six weeks https://t.co/E0Sddi1ere
From @WSJopinion: The courts are repudiating the Biden Administration’s vaccine mandates at an astonishing pace https://t.co/E5HaxNzxyC
How Elon Musk became a high-profile cheerleader of China's Communist Party https://t.co/Rqs94GdfCB
Quentin Durward, a neurosurgeon living in Dakota Dunes, S.D., has a 2020 Ford GT Heritage Edition that evokes the classic racers that beat Ferrari in the 1960s https://t.co/j6gXMBS9LH
At least 70 people have died, Kentucky’s governor estimated, after severe weather and tornadoes caused catastrophic damage across several states https://t.co/iC4dNHTnZ1
U.S. voters are pessimistic about the economy and short on confidence in President Biden’s leadership, a WSJ poll found https://t.co/eQhMCivdld

“Honestly, I would just can this whole bill.” Tesla CEO Elon Musk criticized federal efforts meant to spur electric-vehicle adoption, including a bill that would boost incentives for buying battery-powered cars #WSJWhatsNow https://t.co/gMzyxzaxX8
Due to the Amazon cloud outage, a couple had to "manually" feed their cats "like in ancient times" https://t.co/I1GUQbJPY2
Singapore will stop covering Covid-19 medical costs for those who choose to go unvaccinated https://t.co/mP5T1ytfmL
Austria’s Covid-19 infections have plummeted and vaccination rates have soared after the country imposed a lockdown and said it would make the shots mandatory https://t.co/JRROnb23VG
The United Arab Emirates is shifting to a 4½-day workweek that will start Monday and end on Friday at noon https://t.co/U53BG7otQ0

Essay: Hardships that hasten children’s cognitive development can harm their prospects as adults, according to recent research. What they need is the safety to play and explore. https://t.co/e8uVQFlHQd
Australia is joining the U.S. in a diplomatic boycott of the 2022 Winter Olympics in Beijing https://t.co/IrFKwYIkWh
Essay: The late Hugo Chavez’s embrace of Fidel Castro and the Cuban regime sent Venezuela into a spiral of poverty and chaos https://t.co/tjQI8FsmZl
Omicron was able to elude two doses of the Covid-19 vaccine from Pfizer and BioNTech in initial lab testing, but three doses neutralized the variant, the companies said https://t.co/qfdW9iy6uL

From @WSJopinion: The best way to help working families is to cut their tax bills, which helps not only families using child-care facilities but also those providing the best care available—at home with mom or dad https://t.co/lLF2Js9FNf
From @WSJopinion: Merrick Garland’s Justice Department is pursuing an even more partisan agenda than it did in the Obama years, writes @KimStrassel https://t.co/YhaPGmADky
The backlog of container ships off the ports of Los Angeles and Long Beach isn’t getting smaller—it just looks that way https://t.co/o9Nfn2x3FO
Take a look at the front page of today's Wall Street Journal https://t.co/Y5XvBLtSDF https://t.co/n0VkHytxLK
Japan's restless seniors try team videogaming. “It’s better than having nothing to do at home and watching TV." https://t.co/mDaApwDKU6
Here is an early look at the front page of The Wall Street Journal's weekend edition https://t.co/IdXxaSgzzy https://t.co/VugPWezud5
The Omicron variant has so far caused mostly mild cases of Covid-19 in a small group of largely vaccinated people in the U.S., CDC data show https://t.co/UwQsVf6GhX
From @WSJopinion: The Biden Administration ignored the law. Now the vaccine mandates are getting crushed in court. https://t.co/9MNe7ElgIf
Breaking: The Supreme Court ruled that abortion clinics can challenge Texas’ ban on most abortions, putting the law in jeopardy even though it remains in effect for now https://t.co/WuGfkOH57P
Elon Musk, CEO of Tesla and SpaceX, said he might quit his jobs, without providing details about which positions he might relinquish or how serious he was about changing roles https://t.co/vHIKIAxfKH
GM plans to invest more than $3 billion to make electric vehicles in Michigan, people familiar with the matter said https://t.co/jKz3CPkpP8
Why Mark Zuckerberg may be wrong about the metaverse as the inevitable next leap forward in computer interfaces https://t.co/aEOYBoyALD

U.S. inflation is at its highest rate in nearly four decades this fall, reaching 6.8% in November from a year ago. Why do prices keep going up and what's the cause? The reasons are myriad—the pandemic is one. https://t.co/OA3LOcpLdY

An elite group of U.S.-trained Somali commandos has become so entangled in local political power struggles that it has ceased operations against the Islamist militants it was created to fight https://t.co/iq3mKal2Uc
The U.A.E. recently ordered work halted on a Chinese facility in the country after American officials argued that Beijing intended to use the site for military purposes https://t.co/C2lPyV1QRs
From @WSJopinion: Kamala Harris’s shaky standing is a danger to the country given the position she could be called on to fill, writes @Peggynoonannyc https://t.co/X3moCatbwQ
U.S. inflation hit a 39-year high of 6.8% last month. Consumer demand and supply shortages continue to pressure prices. https://t.co/H2vCq7YPNr
From @WSJopinion: Yes, the crime wave is as bad as you think. Progressives gaslight the public by claiming things used to be worse, writes @Rafa_Mangual https://t.co/4owMvQjj4d

The nation’s large and diverse group of Hispanic voters is showing signs of dividing its support between Democrats and Republicans more evenly than in recent elections, a new Wall Street Journal poll finds https://t.co/V3jTLXz3H7
Company leaders are unloading stock at a record pace. Top insiders, like Elon Musk and Mark Zuckerberg, sold more than $63.5 billion this year, a WSJ analysis shows. https://t.co/nV0Wyh6RJK

Watch as baristas at a Buffalo, N.Y., Starbucks store realized they had enough votes to unionize, making them the first labor union at one of the coffee giant’s own U.S. cafes #WSJWhatsNow https://t.co/YSDanIzDj4
The U.S. won an appeal against a U.K. court's decision to bar the extradition of Julian Assange, clearing a hurdle in its pursuit of the WikiLeaks founder https://t.co/2s3Pnx0DGh
From @WSJopinion: A new poll from Gallup confirms that the American people still have more faith in capitalism than they do in socialism https://t.co/HDnyZoT5cE

GE, Union Pacific and other large employers have suspended Covid-19 vaccine requirements for workers after a court ruling blocked the Biden administration's mandate for federal contractors https://t.co/nLsYx38XsP

The U.S. plans to ban American investment in Chinese AI company SenseTime and is looking to block SMIC, China's largest chip maker, from buying U.S. manufacturing tools, people familiar with the matter said https://t.co/9wt7VA8466
“If it’s gone, it’s a big deal.” Researchers want to know if one of the four main influenza strains that infect humans has disappeared https://t.co/IjvUV2j3Kf
Breaking: Actor Jussie Smollett was found guilty of lying to police when he reported being the victim of a hate crime near his Chicago apartment in 2019 https://t.co/krRkbVXm4e
An appeals court rejected former President Trump's bid to block the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 riot from gaining access to records from his presidency https://t.co/hik04N1StN

New York City lawmakers are set to vote on a bill that would let more than 800,000 residents who aren’t U.S. citizens vote in local elections, potentially becoming the largest city in the U.S. to do so https://t.co/A4ozeJbp6J
The holiday shopping season makes us prime targets for cybercriminals. Here’s how to avoid some of the most popular scams plus other tips for online safety https://t.co/YsTLizQUx4
The Senate approved legislation aimed at nullifying President Biden’s vaccine-or-test mandate for private employers https://t.co/IMYfuxAqAl
Starbucks baristas in Buffalo, N.Y. voted to form the first labor union at one the coffee giant’s U.S. cafes in the company’s 50-year history https://t.co/gGC1tGneTZ

Half of Americans support President Biden’s Covid-19 vaccine requirements for private-sector employers, and a slim majority backs other state and local mandates, a new Wall Street Journal poll finds https://t.co/Xe4i4aux5L
New York Attorney General Letitia James said she is ending her bid for governor and will seek another term in her current office https://t.co/hIzDImGOXn

Rupert Murdoch purchased a 340,000-acre Montana cattle ranch from the Koch family for roughly $200 million, making it the largest ranch sale in state history, people with knowledge of the deal said https://t.co/YMzg1FftKq
